results.title: Quilts in women's lives
results.creator_credit: New Day Films and Pat Ferrero
results.brief_description: A multi-award winning film on the traditional art of quiltmaking and its affect on the lives of seven women. Each from quite diverse backgrounds, the women discuss the influences that inspire quilt design, and how their lives and times are depicted in their work.
results.description: A multi-award winning film on the traditional art of quiltmaking and its affect on the lives of seven women. Each from quite diverse backgrounds, the women discuss the influences that inspire quilt design, and how their lives and times are depicted in their work.

results.title: Quills
results.creator_credit: Fox Searchlight Pictures, Hollywood Partners, Industry Entertainment, Walrus and Associates, Julia Chasma, Peter Kaufman, Nick Wechsler and Philip Kaufman
results.brief_description: Paris, 1804 - following the bloody climate of the French Revolution erotic writer, the Marquis de Sade, resides in the Charenton Asylum for the insane where he continues to pen his sadomasochistic literature. When his latest tome upsets Napoleon, Dr Royer-Collard (Michael Caine) is despatched to ensure that de Sade be published no more. In charge of the asylum is a benevolent priest Coulmier (Joaquin Phoenix) who allows de Sade’s writings as a form of therapy. Coulmier and Royer-Collard soon come into conflict about the treatment of the Marquis and the running of the asylum. But the priest faces a greater challenge - his lust for a common laundress sparks suppressed desires, but it is she who is sneaking out the Marquis’ incendiary prose. Meanwhile the doctor marries a virginal bride, brought up in a nunnery, who he mercilessly abuses. Philip Kaufman (The Unbearable lightness of being, Henry and June, The Right stuff) presents the Marquis de Sade as a mostly harmless presence (ignoring his historical squalidity) - compared to the enshrined corruption within the Church. Kaufman ably captures the fetid environs of the asylum; the barely contained carnal desires of the inmates, their depravity and insanity, inflaming the nightmarish atmosphere of these scenes. Rush puts in an impressive, if manic, performance as a tormented artist, whose prose may inspire acts of passion and murder witnessed throughout the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fox Searchlight Pictures, Hollywood Partners, Industry Entertainment, Walrus and Associates, Julia Chasma, Peter Kaufman, Nick Wechsler and Philip Kaufman

results.title: Quill
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts and Jo Kennedy
results.brief_description: A woman’s desire to write is literally inscribed onto her body when her breasts begin to leak ink. Cast includes Sally Cooper, Belinda McCory.

results.title: Quigley
results.creator_credit: Pathe Entertainment, Stanley O'Toole, Alex Rose and Simon Wincer
results.brief_description: Tom Selleck stars as Matthew Quigley, an American hired gun who answers a “Help Wanted” ad and finds himself in Australia. Alan Rickman plays the evil, British cattle rancher who hires Quigley. Quigley refuses the job and is left stranded in the outback with a crazy woman called Cora (Laura San Giacomo). Essentially a western in an outback setting, the film also features Chris Haywood, Tony Bonner and Ben Mendelson.

results.title: Quiet man with welding torch: a portrait of sculptor Julio Gonzalez 1876-1942
results.creator_credit: Barrie Gavin, William Leeson, Laurence Boulting, Waveband Film Productions and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
The spanish artist Julio Gonzalez (1876-1942) has been recognised along with Brancusi and Picasso as one of the most important sculptors of the 20th Century in his generation responsible for ‘opening the most doors for 20th century sculpture’. A man of acute sensibilities whose ‘aesthetics of poverty’ gave birth to a legacy that celebrated found junk-metal and iron scraps making elegant and poignant sculptural forms. The documentary examines the sculptors past as jeweller and his growing aesthetic and technical methods throughout his career. A fearful man who lived a simple life away from publicity and the art world after the volatile period surrounding the world wars in Europe and the Spanish civil war. Narrated by Lyndon Brook.

results.title: Quiet crisis
results.brief_description: A dramatised story of a typical cancer case. This film is a plea for an early visit to the doctor by anyone having the slightest suspicion of the disease. Shows that with early treatment by improved methods, cancer may often be cured while delay can prove to be fatal. Note: This film had been viewed by medical experts and it is considered that the treatment portrayed in the film is not in accord with actual treatment as available in Victoria.

results.title: Quiddity tree
results.creator_credit: Marvin Albert Films and Marvin Albert
results.brief_description: This prize winning film is a fantasy about man and nature, in which the inter-relationships of man and his environment are symbolically revealed. Experimental in its treatment, the film carries the message that man must preserve his environment in every way possible - not destroy it.

results.title: Quick rise
results.brief_description: Time lapse photography is used to speed up the action in a town and a twenty storey building goes from ground level to completion in hour minutes. Visual speed is enhanced by a lively Bach piece preformed on a Moog synthesiser.

results.title: Qui? = Who?
results.brief_description:
A car rides off a cliff. The female passenger survives the ordeal, her male companion, the driver does not. The brother of the dead man takes the young woman back to his place. Although he suspects her to have something to do with his brother’s death, he is inexplicably attracted to her. The police recovers the dead body and for a while the suspicions a laid to rest. But the ‘dead man’ reappears not long after 

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Leonard Keigel ; writers, Leonard Keigel, Paul Gegauff ; photography, Jean Bourgoin ; music, Claude Bolling.
Cast: Romy Schneider, Maurice Ronet, Simone Bach, Jacques Duby, Gabriele Tinti.

results.title: Qui Etes-Vous Monsieur Sorge? = Who Are You, Mister Sorge?
results.brief_description:
This war time docudrama is based on real life events. Richard Sorge was from 1935 through 1943 working at the German embassy in Japan. Sorge was also a Russian spy, leaking out secret invasion plans in preparation for the anticipated Soviet takeover of Japan after the war. After his activities were uncovered, people say he was tried and hanged by the Japanese in 1944. Others suspect he may have been exchanged. His faithful secretary thinks Sorge paid for other people’s mistakes. The film attempts to discover the truth by following with great minutiae the last months of Sorge’s life.

Credits: Producer, Jean Cotet ; director, Yves Ciampi ; writers, Yves Ciampi, Rodolphe-Maurice Arlaud ; photography, Emile Villerbue, T. Ubukata ; music, Serge Nigg.
Cast: Thomas Holtzmann, Hans-Otto Meissner, Keiko Kishi, Nadine Basile, Jacques Berthier, Jesse Hahn.
